titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the University of Hartford Studies in Literature ARCH031
titlestmt.author: Sean Parke

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Hartford Archives & Special Collections

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-04-09 14:47:07 -0400.

repository.corpname: University of Hartford Archives & Special Collections

did.unittitle: University of Hartford Studies in Literature collection

physdesc.extent: (13 containers total - 3 boxes and 10 bound books)

dao.xlink:title: Digitized University of Hartford Studies in Literature collection

daodesc.p: Digitized University of Hartford Studies in Literature collection: 1969 - 1991

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection may be protected by copyright law (U.S. Code: Title 17). Any use of the material which exceeds fair use requires permission from the copyright holder. Researchers are solely responsible for obtaining the proper permission(s) for their use of the material.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Some earlier issues have been digitized and are available here: http://mdid3b.hartford.edu/explore/explore/?c=allcollections:74. Access to the digital repository is limited to the University of Hartford Campus. Computers are available to the public at the Harrison Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From 1969 to 1977 the publication was known as Hartford Studies in Literature (HSL), until 1977 when the publication changed to University of Hartford Studies in Literature (UHSL).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2015, the call number was changed from E10.H to ARCH031 to avoid duplication. This collection was a part of the University of Hartford Publications Collection (formerly "E" now ARCH032), but was sepearted as its own collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains every issue of the University of Hartford Studies in Literature (UHSL) from 1969 - 1991, as well as a few memorandums, press releases, clippings, and a photograph.

Hartford Studies in Literature, Vol. 1, No. 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume 1, Number 1. Front Matter (pg. 1); 2001 and the Paradox of the Fortunate Fall, BY ALAN BRODY (pg. 7); 2001: A Psychosocial Explication, BY NORMAN N. HOLLAND (pg. 20); Sons and Fathers, A.D. 2001, BY ROBERT PLANK (pg.26); The Psychology of the 'Double' in 2001, BY ROBERT ROGERS (pg. 34); A Plurality of After-Worlds: Isaac Taylor and Alfred Tennyson, BY MILTON MILLHAUSER (pg. 37); Some Literary Uses of Numerology, BY JOHN T. SHAWCROSS (pg. 50); Book Review, Humans and Humanoids, BY MARVIN REZNIKOFF (pg. 63); Book Notes (pg. 68).

Imperfect Androgyny and Imperfect Love in the Works of Carson McCullers, By Mary Roberts (pg. 73); The Dark Sources of Love: A Jungian Reading of Two Early James Novels, By Annette Larson Benert (pg. 99); Caddy and Quentin: Anima and Animus Orbited Nice, By Steve Carter (pg. 124); Self and Object Representations in As I Lay Dying, By Deborah Ayer Sitter (pg. 143); The Usable Past: Van Wyck Brooks, By Calvin W. Lane (pg. 156). ERRATUM: Deborah Ayer Sitter, whose article, "Self and Object Representations in As I Lay Dying," appeared in Vol. 12, No. 2, does not teach at Emory University but at Spelman College, also in Atlanta.

did.unittitle: University of Hartford Studies in Literature, Vol. 13, No. 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume 13, Number 1. John Inglesant, Victorian Cavalier: History as Faith in the 1880s, By Joanne Hutchinson (pg. 1); Contradictions Unresolved: Figural Art in the 1880s, By Susan Casteras (pg. 17); The Artists' Colony at Broadway, England, By Beth Treadway (pg. 41); Eden and Apocalypse: William Morris' Marxist Vision in the 1880s, By Carole Silver (pg. 62); Jude the Obscure: A Psychoanalytic Study, By Carol and Duane Edwards (pg. 78). This issue is dedicated to the memory of ELEANOR BLACKMAN MANHEIM, 1901 - 1981, associated with University of Hartford Studies in Literature as Associate Editor since its founding in 1968. This is a special issue which "collects papers (not delivered at the conference itself) on the art, religion, history, and literature of that decade in which High Victorianism was being challenged by forces that would shape the modern world."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume 16, Number 2 and 3. INTERDISCIPLINARY CRITICISM, Essays in Memory of Leonard Manheim. "The essays in this special double issue were commissioned to honor the late Leonard Manheim 1902-1983), founder and editor of Literature and Psychology (1951-1967) and University of Hartford Studies in Literature (1969-1983), teacher, controversialist, and inspiring colleague." Driving in Gainesville, Florida: The Shared and The Individual in literary Response, By Nonnan Holland (pg. 1); The New Discourse of Mass Culture: Magazines in the 1890s, By Richard Ohmann (pg. 16); Interpretive Extremes: The Old Instrument Players and Recent Literary Criticism, By James Winn (pg. 36); From Mannerism to Modernism: The Playful Artifice of Walter Pater, By Paul Barolsky (pg. 47); Philosophy and Poetry: The New Rapprochement, By Carl Rapp (pg. 58); Understanding and Truth in The Two Cultures, By Paul Armstrong (pg. 70); "There Was Meaning in His Look": The Meeting of Pictorial Models in Joyce's "Nausicaa," By Wendy Steiner (pg. 90); Literary Counselors For the Defense: Socrates and Gandhi, By Jean· Pierre Barricelli (pg. 104); Leonard Manheim as a Dickens Critic, By Michael Steig (pg. 111); Contributors (pg. 116).
